flow.context: Stephen Petasky is Founder & CEO of Luxus Vacation Properties, a luxury STR management brand operating across Palm Springs, Hawaii, and other markets. He controls rollout of new ops tech company-wide and has publicly discussed PropTech and AI in luxury travel on the Millionaire Mindcast podcast. Luxus uses Guesty for their owner portal and Vintory for lead gen — no Breezeway or dedicated inspection platform was detected publicly. Key team below him: Greg Stevenson (VP Portfolio & Ops) and Tammy Kelly (Homeowner & Guest Services Manager). Sam connection: Stephen is based out of San Diego, Sam grew up in the LA area — plus the PropTech/AI podcast angle makes this topically warm.

gatekeeper.label: SOMEONE PICKS UP
gatekeeper.say: Hey — could you get me through to Stephen? It's Sam.
gatekeeper.note: If Stephen himself answers and says 'This is Stephen,' jump straight to the opener. This line is for when someone else picks up first.

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — MORE CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah, I work with a few other property managers in the Palm Springs area. Would you mind letting him know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Dose info slowly. Don't pitch. End with a redirect question that moves toward a transfer.

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: We help a couple other vacation rental management companies with their turnover inspection workflows. I shot him a note — would you mind giving him a heads up?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: Last dose of info for the gatekeeper. If this doesn't land, get a callback time and try again later.

branches.label: Take a message / Send an email

gatekeeper_unavailable.label: GATEKEEPER — NOT AVAILABLE
gatekeeper_unavailable.say: No worries at all. Do you know when he's usually easiest to catch? I'll try him back then.
gatekeeper_unavailable.note: Get a specific day and time window. Write it down. Call back at exactly that time.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Stephen — I caught that Millionaire Mindcast episode where you talked about PropTech and AI shaping luxury travel. Really cool stuff. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around?
opener.note: Feet up on the desk energy. The podcast reference shows genuine interest and is topically aligned with RapidEye. Pause after the question and wait for his response.

branches.label: Who is this? / What do you want?

heard_yes.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone in your world. What'd you hear?
heard_yes.note: Let him talk. Whatever he says, bridge into discovery. Don't correct or over-explain.

heard_no.label: HAVEN'T HEARD — TRANSITION
heard_no.say: Ha — clearly not as popular as I thought. Well the reason I'm calling — I work with a handful of luxury STR operators running portfolios across multiple markets, and I wanted to run something by you real quick.
heard_no.note: Keep the energy light. This flows directly into the pain trigger. Don't pause too long here — carry the momentum forward.

branches.label: Not interested / What are you selling?

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow or later this week?
bad_timing.note: Don't fight it. Be easy about it. Get a specific callback window if possible.

branches.label: He gives a day or time

reschedule.label: CALLBACK LOCKED
reschedule.say: Perfect — I'll try you then. Really appreciate it, Stephen.
reschedule.note: Write down the exact day and time immediately. Set a calendar reminder. Call back at precisely that time — this is now a warm callback.

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION — 30 SECONDS
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call, I'll be straight with you. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out? You can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit.
permission_fallback.note: Disarm with honesty. Acknowledging the cold call resets the dynamic. Smile when you say it.

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED — LAST SHOT
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and it's just not interesting?
permission_rejected.note: This is the split. 'Horrible time' reopens the door to a callback. 'Not interesting' means close gracefully. Don't push past this point.

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER — THE PROBLEM
pain_trigger.say: So I was talking to another CEO running luxury short-term rentals across a bunch of different markets — pretty similar to what you guys are building at Luxus. His biggest frustration was that as they added new destinations, turnover quality kept drifting. His teams were snapping photos after every clean, but nobody had the bandwidth to actually review them all. Damage, staging issues, missing items — stuff just slipped right through. And the first person to notice was either the next guest leaving a one-star review, or the homeowner calling in wondering how their place got trashed.
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE HERE. Let that sit for a beat. Wait for Stephen to react before moving to the solution. If he relates, go warm. If he's just listening quietly, continue to solution_cta.

branches.label: Yeah, we deal with that / That resonates
That's not really our issue / We handle that

solution_cta.label: SOLUTION + CTA
solution_cta.say: We built an AI that plugs into the turnover photos your teams are already taking — works right alongside Guesty — and flags damage, missing items, staging problems automatically before the next guest walks in. No workflow change, no new hardware. Would you be open to taking a look when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue?
solution_cta.note: One sentence for the solution, one for the CTA. Mentioning Guesty shows you did your homework. Then stop talking and let him respond.

branches.label: Yeah, I'd be open to that
Pushback — budget, not interested, have something
That's more of an ops thing / Not my area

warm_response.label: WARM — STOP PITCHING
warm_response.say: Yeah, I hear that from a lot of operators at your scale. Honestly before I ramble — what does that look like for you guys? When a turnover issue slips through at Luxus, how does that usually surface?
warm_response.note: He's interested. STOP PITCHING. Switch to questions. Let Stephen talk. You're learning his world, not selling.

branches.label: Keeps it high-level / Asks what you actually do

discovery_priorities.label: DISCOVERY — CEO PRIORITIES
discovery_priorities.say: That makes a lot of sense. You guys are in Palm Springs, Hawaii, and expanding — what's the biggest operational priority heading into the next season? Is it scaling into new markets or more about tightening up quality in the ones you've already got?
discovery_priorities.note: CEO-level question. Map where inspections fit in his strategic world. Listen for: growth plans, owner retention concerns, quality consistency across destinations, staffing challenges.

branches.label: Wants to hear more about RapidEye

discovery_process.label: DISCOVERY — CURRENT PROCESS
discovery_process.say: Got it. And right now — how are your teams actually documenting turnovers across the different markets? Is it photos through Guesty, a separate checklist system, or does it kind of vary by location?
discovery_process.note: Map their current workflow. No Breezeway or Matterport was found publicly — they may be doing this manually or inconsistently across destinations. Every gap he mentions is ammo for the meeting.

branches.label: That's really more of a Greg or ops question

bridge_to_meeting.label: BRIDGE TO MEETING
bridge_to_meeting.say: This is exactly the kind of stuff we dig into with operators at your scale. I don't want to eat up your whole afternoon on a cold call though — would it make sense to carve out 20 minutes this week? I can show you what we're doing with a couple other luxury portfolios and you can see if it's even relevant for Luxus.
bridge_to_meeting.note: Transition to booking. The meeting is framed as valuable even if they never buy. 'Operators at your scale' is peer framing. Don't oversell.

branches.label: Loop in Greg / my ops team for this

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — INITIAL PUSHBACK
objection_not_interested.say: Totally get it. I should've assumed you'd be all set — with properties across this many markets you'd have to have something figured out by now.
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first. Surprise him by not fighting. This validates him and resets the dynamic. Then move to the split to understand the real blocker.

interest_split.label: SPLIT — FIND THE REAL OBJECTION
interest_split.say: Just so nobody from my team follows up if it's not relevant — is it more that there's no room in the budget for something like this right now, that you've already got turnover quality locked down and it's handled, or that this is really more of an ops-level thing someone else on your team would own?
interest_split.note: Three-way split: budget, vendor satisfaction, or delegation. Each opens a completely different path. Listen carefully to which one Stephen picks.

branches.label: We've got it handled / Happy with current setup
That's ops / Greg handles that kind of thing

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Nowadays it's harder to keep a tool, let alone buy something new — especially when you're managing costs across a bunch of different destinations.
objection_no_budget.note: Validate the budget concern. Show you understand the multi-market cost pressure. Then move to the budget split.

budget_split.label: BUDGET — SPLIT
budget_split.say: Is it that budget for this cycle is completely locked down, or is it more that anything new has to go through a whole approval chain?
budget_split.note: 'Locked down' is a timing issue — schedule a future conversation. 'Approval chain' means you can help him build the internal case or reach whoever approves spend.

branches.label: Approval process / Scott or the board decides
Truly not spending on anything new

objection_have_vendor.label: OBJECTION — HAVE SOMETHING IN PLACE
objection_have_vendor.say: That makes total sense. With the number of properties you guys manage across destinations, you'd have to have something dialed in already.
objection_have_vendor.note: Validate. Don't attack their current process or tool. Then split to understand if they're truly satisfied or if switching is just painful.

vendor_split.label: VENDOR — SPLIT
vendor_split.say: Just curious — is it that you're fully covered and happy with how things are working, or is it more that ripping anything out and replacing it right now would just be a nightmare?
vendor_split.note: If happy, respect it but offer the comparison view. If switching is the issue, RapidEye doesn't replace their tools — it layers on top of what they already use. That's your opening.

test_drive.label: TEST DRIVE — SELL THE MEETING
test_drive.say: Look, you're probably not buying anything off a cold call today, and I totally respect that. But when this does come up — next budget cycle, next time a homeowner calls about damage nobody caught — the people who move fast are the ones who already know what's out there. If nothing else, I could walk you through what a couple other luxury operators in the Palm Springs market are doing with their turnover photos. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends.
test_drive.note: You're selling the meeting, not the product. The 'other operators in Palm Springs' line is real — ACME House Co uses Breezeway and Matterport. You know things Stephen would want to know about his competitive landscape.

branches.label: Talk to Greg / my ops team

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Awesome. I've got next Tuesday and Thursday pulled up — does either afternoon work for you? Even 20 minutes is plenty.
book_meeting.note: Give two specific days. Lock the time NOW. Don't say 'I'll send a link' — commit to a concrete slot. Send the calendar invite while still on the phone if possible.

meeting_confirmed.label: MEETING BOOKED — STOP SELLING
meeting_confirmed.say: Perfect, I'll shoot you the invite right now. Really appreciate you taking my call, Stephen — looking forward to it.
meeting_confirmed.note: STOP SELLING. The meeting is booked. Don't add features, don't pitch again, don't keep talking. Be grateful, be brief, let him go.

send_email_request.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email_request.say: Totally fair. One quick question before I do — what would be most useful to include so it's not just another generic pitch sitting in your inbox?
send_email_request.note: Accept the email request, then get intel to tailor it. Whatever he says becomes the hook of your follow-up email.

branches.label: Tells you what he'd want to see

email_tailoring.label: EMAIL — TAILOR AND CONFIRM
email_tailoring.say: Got it — I'll put something together around that and shoot it over today. What's the best email for you? I'll drop a couple time options in there for next week in case you want to hop on a quick call after you've had a look.
email_tailoring.note: Get his direct email address. Include two specific meeting times in the follow-up. Reference this conversation in the subject line. Follow up in 48 hours if no response.

referral_ask.label: REFERRAL — WHO OWNS THIS?
referral_ask.say: Totally makes sense — at your level you're probably not in the weeds on turnover workflows day to day. Who on your team would typically own that piece? Is that more of an ops leader or someone on the property management side?
referral_ask.note: You already know Greg Stevenson is VP of Portfolio & Ops and Tammy Kelly is Homeowner & Guest Services Manager. If Stephen mentions either name, act like it's new info. Don't reveal your research.

branches.label: Mentions a name / Points to ops
Not sure / Doesn't want to share

referral_name.label: REFERRAL — GET THE NAME
referral_name.say: That's super helpful. If I could get their best contact info, I'll put something tailored together so it actually lands — instead of just another cold outreach. Would it be cool if I mentioned you pointed me their way?
referral_name.note: Getting permission to name-drop Stephen is huge. It turns the next call from cold to warm. If he says Greg Stevenson, you now have a warm intro to the ideal buyer — the VP of Portfolio & Ops.

branches.label: Gives name and contact / Okay to use his name

referral_outreach.label: REFERRAL — CONFIRM NEXT STEP
referral_outreach.say: Awesome — really appreciate that, Stephen. I'll reach out to them this week and keep it relevant. Thanks for pointing me in the right direction.
referral_outreach.note: You have the referral. Stop talking. Call that person within 24 hours while Stephen's memory of this conversation is fresh. Open the next call with 'Stephen Petasky suggested I reach out.'

end_graceful.label: GRACEFUL EXIT
end_graceful.say: Totally understand. If anything changes on your end, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks, RapidEye. Appreciate your time, Stephen.
end_graceful.note: Don't burn the bridge. Be warm. He might google you after hanging up. Your name and company name are the last things he hears.
